steps.title: Set up mason lines to mark the locations of your landscape timbers.
steps.content: Set up mason lines to mark the locations of your landscape timbers. For a simple garden edge with a rectangular design, set up stakes at all 4 corners of your garden, and pull a mason line taut between each stake. If your planned garden is large enough that it’s difficult to keep a single line taut between two stakes, add an additional stake midway along your garden’s length or width. [1] X Research source If you don’t have a mason line, any other kind of string can work just as well. For ease of access, try not to have your timbers set at a width of more than 4 feet (1.2) meters from each other if you’re planning on creating a garden. [2] X Research source Although the length of the rectangle can be as long as you’d like, if the rectangle is too long, it’ll be difficult to reach your plants without stepping in your garden. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Dig trenches 3 inches (7.5 cm) deep along the mason lines.
steps.content: Dig trenches 3 inches (7.5 cm) deep along the mason lines. For tough turf, use a sharp spade . [4] X Research source These trenches will need to be wide enough to accommodate the size of your timber—usually 4 to 6 inches (10 to 15 cm) across. Remove as much organic matter, like roots or other plant residue, as you can. [5] X Research source If you’re working on a shallow slope (under 10 degrees), dig approximately 8 inches (20 cm) into the ground from the higher end of the slope. For steeper slopes, dig 12 inches (30.5 cm) into the ground. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Tamp down the ground to create a level surface.
steps.content: Tamp down the ground to create a level surface. Run a level along the bottom of your trenches, removing or adding dirt as needed to create a level surface. With your hands or the back of your spade, tamp down the soil at the bottom of the trenches. [7] X Research source To add longevity to your timbers, add a layer of sand or gravel about an inch (2.5 cm) thick to the bottom of your trenches. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Install landscape fabric if you want to keep out weeds.
steps.content: Install landscape fabric if you want to keep out weeds. To do this, roll landscape fabric over the trenches, then drive it into the ground with small stakes and a hammer. Trim any extra fabric that hangs out over the edges. [9] X Research source This step is optional—if you aren’t worried about weeds in or around your trenches, it’s okay to skip this step.

steps.title: You may need shorter pieces of timber to fill out your trenches.
steps.content: You may need shorter pieces of timber to fill out your trenches. Measure the length of each trench, and use this information to decide how many pieces of timber you’ll need. If you need a shorter piece of timber at the ends of each trench in order to match its length, mark the length of timber you need on a longer piece, then cut it . A circular saw works great for this, but a hand saw can also do the trick. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Line up the pieces of timber so that they’re a snug fit in the trenches.
steps.content: Line up the pieces of timber so that they’re a snug fit in the trenches. Use a level after placing each log so that you can be sure they’re level against the ground. If a piece isn’t flat against the ground of the trench, add or remove some soil from underneath it. [11] X Research source To make sure your timber edging lasts for a long time, use rot-resistant wood. Cypress, cedar, redwood, or pressure-treated wood can last beyond 7 years, while less durable options might need to be replaced earlier. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Place a second layer of timber on top of your first layer.
steps.content: Place a second layer of timber on top of your first layer. Be sure that the layers of timber line up smoothly. If you’re having trouble making sure the second layer is level, place wood shims between the levels. [13] X Research source This step is only necessary if you want a taller garden edging. If you’re satisfied with the height of a single layer of timber, there’s no need to install a second.

steps.title: Drill 2 holes on each log, 2 inches (5 cm) from each end.
steps.content: Drill 2 holes on each log, 2 inches (5 cm) from each end. Pre-drill your wood with a power drill. Use a drill bit that is slightly smaller than the size of the rebar stakes that you’ll eventually be placing into it. By doing so, you can prevent your wood from becoming damaged. [14] X Research source If you have 2 or more layers of timber, drill through all of them at the same locations.

steps.title: Driving rebar stakes into the holes you drilled will secure your timber.
steps.content: Driving rebar stakes into the holes you drilled will secure your timber. Place the end of a rebar stake into the hole that you pre-drilled. Then, drive it through the wood and into the ground with a hammer. Use a hammer to push the rebar stakes through the timber, ideally using rods or rebar stakes long enough to be driven 2 feet (0.6 meters) into the ground. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Tidy up the edging by filling in any gaps with dirt.
steps.content: Tidy up the edging by filling in any gaps with dirt. For any areas near the timber that aren’t level with the ground around it, add dirt or soil. Tamp down any gaps that you’ve filled with soil. This will keep your timber even more secure and create an attractive garden edge. [16] X Research source
